The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

argument.p: Containing the mo≈øt Remarkable Occurrences of his Life, from the flight of the Queen Mother in 1631, to the Year 1634.

div.p:
year 1631 BEFORE the Queen-Mother went out of France, as I have already ob≈øerv'd in the preceding Book, the King ≈øent to the Parliament of Paris the ≈øame Declaration which he had caus'd to be Confirm'd in that of Dijon, wherein he Declar'd all the Adherents of the Duke of Orleans to be guilty of High-Trea≈øon. But the Parliament of Paris made ≈øome difficulty to confirm it without any foregoing Deliberation, as the King de≈øir'd them; and this they grounded upon the following Rea≈øons.
Fir≈øt, This Declaration again≈øt all u≈øual Forms had been laid before another Parliament be≈øides that of Paris, which alone is the Court of Peers, and the fir≈øt Parliament of the Kingdom.
Secondly, It, by Name, declared a Pre≈øident to be guilty, who, by this means, would be condemned by the Court without being heard.
Thirdly, This Declaration might reach even the Per≈øon of the Duke of Orleans, who≈øe Intere≈øt had been always dear to the Parliament. They cameThe 25 of Ap. Aubery's Life of the Card. Lib. iv. c. 17. Siri Mem. Rec. T. 7. P. 358. therefore to a Deliberation, and the Company divided, in≈øtead of Voting the Confirmation which the King demanded.

Our Mini≈øter not able to endure that they ≈øhould ≈øhow the lea≈øt con≈øideration for his Enemies, per≈øwaded the King to go quickly toThe 12th of May. Paris, to have his Declaration Confirmed, and to give ≈øome Mortification to the Parliament. The King being arriv'd at the Louvre, ≈øent Orders to the Parliament to come thither in a Body on foot. The Parliament obeyed, and were conducted to the Gallery which joyns the Tuilleries with the Louvre, where they found the King under a Canopy rai≈øed up for that purpo≈øe. The Lord Keeper Spoke fir≈øt; and after the fir≈øt Ceremonies were over, told the Parliament, That their Power extended onely to the Affairs of private Men, and not to matters of State, the cogni≈øance of which belonged to the Supreme Governour: That where a Prince, or Duke, or any Officer of the Crown, receives his Trial for any Mi≈ødemeanour in the Admini≈øtration of the Trea≈øury, or of State-Affairs, his Maje≈øty is obliged, either to direct a particular Commi≈ø≈øion to the Parliament, to enable them to Act in ≈øuch a ca≈øe; or el≈øe to be pre≈øent him≈øelf Per≈øonally, to Authorize the≈øe extraordinary Proceedings: That it is true indeed, that to Judge by a Commi≈ø≈øion required a previous knowledge of the Cau≈øe, but that in the ca≈øe of Ratifying a Declaration, which always allows a certain time to tho≈øe that are Guilty to return to their Duty, there was no need of farther Deliberation. This was as much as to ≈øay, That the King was willing to make u≈øe of the Parliamentary Authority, to de≈øtroy with more formality tho≈øe who favoured his Brother; but would not allow the Parliament the Power of Clearing them if they were innocent.

The≈øe Proceedings again≈øt the Duke of Orleans's Petition were the cau≈øe that the Queen's Reque≈øt, which was ≈øent to the ≈øame Parliament, Packed up with ≈øome other Papers, was not onely broke open, but the Pacquet it ≈øelf was carried to the King. So that the Complaints which this Prince≈øs, and Mon≈øieur made again≈øt the Cardinal, onely ended in a few Printed Pamphlets, which they took care to have thrown about the Streets, or under-hand di≈øtributed; but there was no Tribunal where they might make their Addre≈øs; for as to the King's Council, which depended more upon the Mini≈øter than him≈øelf, it was to no purpo≈øe to make their Application to it. The King him≈øelf was be≈øet with People devoted to the Cardinal, who≈øe continual bu≈øine≈øs it was to entertain him in an Ill Humour again≈øt his neare≈øt Friends and Relations; and as he beheld nothing but by the Eyes of other People, both his Mother and Brother appeared as Guilty before him, as it plea≈øed the Cardinal to repre≈øent them.

Sometime The 12th of Augu≈øt, See Aubery's Life of the Card. Lib. 4. c. 18. after the withdrawing of the Queen-Mother, the King i≈ø≈øued out another Declaration, in which he Defamed this Prince≈øs and the Duke of Orleans; and, on the contrary, be≈øtowed large Commendations on the Cardinal. He ≈øaid, among≈øt other things, That the Evil Coun≈øellours of his Brother had moved him, contrary to the Duty of his Birth, and to that Re≈øpect he owed him to Write him Letters full of Calumnies, and Seditious Lyes again≈øt the Government; That again≈øt all Truth and Rea≈øon he had Accu≈øed his mo≈øt Dear and Well-beloved Cou≈øin the Cardinal of Richlieu, of Infidelity, and of harbouring Ill De≈øigns again≈øt his Sacred Per≈øon, that of the Queen, and his own, and again≈øt the State; That the Queen-Mother had been wrought upon long ago by Ill Coun≈øels, and took more part in the Duke of Orleans's De≈øigns than ≈øhe ought, being, in all probability, induced to it by the Ill Reports which ≈øome Per≈øons profe≈ø≈øing Curious and Evil Sciences had ≈øpread abroad, to give them ≈øome hopes of a ≈øudden Revolution: That having de≈øired the Queen-Mother to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him with her Advice, as ≈øhe had done before; ≈øhe had An≈øwered him, She was weary of meddling with Affairs, and would have no more to do with them; whereby ≈øhe gave him ≈øufficiently to under≈øtand, that ≈øhe was deeply ingag'd in the Duke's De≈øigns: That thereupon he had taken a Re≈øolution to Separate him≈øelf from her for ≈øome time (After this manner did the Cardinal ≈øpeak of the Impri≈øonment of the Queen-Mother, which he called a Separation,) and ≈øo de≈øired her to go to Moulins, which ≈øhe refu≈øed to do; and that ≈øhe onely offered to go to Nevers, while Mon≈øieur was at Orleans, to be nearer to his Per≈øon, but had refu≈øed to do it, when ≈øhe heard that he was gone from thence: That after her departure from Compeigne, ≈øhe had ≈øent a Reque≈øt to the Parliament of Paris, full of fal≈øe and injurious Invectives again≈øt Cardinal Richlieu, and Written a Letter to His Maje≈øty, containing ≈øeveral Studied Pretences to Colour her withdrawing, and many Complaints again≈øt the Cardinal, which had no other foundation, but tho≈øe Calumnies and Fal≈øhoods which were ≈øugge≈øted by the Ill-Coun≈øellours of Mon≈øieur: That both the one and the other
aimed, by the ≈øame means, to endeavour the Subver≈øion of the Royal Authority, and of the Kingdom; That not being yet ≈øatisfied with the fir≈øt Calumnies ≈øhe had Written to His Maje≈øty, ≈øhe wasSee the≈øe Letters in the Collection of Aubery's Memoirs, T. 1. P. 374. be≈øides wrought upon to Write to the Parliament, and to the Provo≈øt of the Merchants of Paris, to per≈øwade them to Revolt, and to give an Ill Example to others. That as he Confirmed all the preceding Declarations, ≈øo he declared all tho≈øe to be guilty of High-Trea≈øon, and Di≈øturbers of the Publick Peace, who ≈øhould be found to have any ≈øhare in ≈øuch Pernicious and Damnable De≈øigns, as to withdraw the Queen-Mother and the Duke of Orleans from their Allegiance, and to induce them to go out of the Kingdom, and likewi≈øe all tho≈øe who had followed them, and were with them: That his Royal Plea≈øure and Will was, that they ≈øhould be proceeded again≈øt, and that he ≈øtrictly prohibited all Per≈øons to keep any Corre≈øpondence either with the Queen-Mother, or the Duke, upon any pretence what≈øoever; and if any of their Letters ≈øhould fall into the hands of his Subjects, they ≈øhould ≈øend them immediately to the Royal Judges of the Provinces, or to the Keeper of the Seals; That all the Mannors which they held of the Crown ≈øhould be ≈øeized upon, and re-united to the King's Deme≈øne; them≈øelves deprived of their Dignities and Offices, and all their E≈øtates forfeited to the King.

This la≈øt Article involved the Queen-Mother and Mon≈øieur, as well as tho≈øe that followed them, the Queen's Dowry, and all the Revenues of the Duke being ≈øtopt and ≈øeized. While the King di≈øhonoured both his Mother and Brother, with ≈øo rigorous a procedure, and took from them all manner of Sub≈øi≈øtance, becau≈øe they had been ≈øo daring as to de≈øire that the Cardinal of Richlieu might be turned out, he heaped new Honours and Favours upon this happy Mini≈øter. HisBy Letters given at Monceaux, in the Month of Augu≈øt. Land of Richlieu was erected into a Dukedom and Peerdom, and there was afterwards a Contention among≈øt the Courts of Parliament, which of them ≈øhould receive this Prelate in the Quality of a Duke and Peer. But at la≈øt it was agreed, That the Great Chamber, that of the Edict, and that of the Tournelle, being A≈ø≈øembled together,
≈øhould receive him, The 4th of September. and he went to take the u≈øual Oath, and to ≈øit in the Parliament, attended by the Prince of Conde, by the Dukes of Montmorency, of Chevreu≈øe, of Montbazon, of Rets, of Ventadour and of Crequi; by the Mare≈øchals, Vitry, Etrees, and Effiat, and by many other Per≈øons of Quality. From that time he was call'd The Cardinal-Duke, as Olivarez, Chief Mini≈øter to the King of Spain, was ≈øtiled the Count-Duke. The King gave him be≈øides the Government of Britany, lately vacant by the death of the Mare≈øchal de Themines. This Government could not fall to any one more advantageou≈øly than to the Cardinal, who being Superintendant both of Navigation and Trade, could ≈øcarce exerci≈øe his Office without being Ma≈øter of the Ports of Britany. This was at the ≈øame time an a≈ø≈øured Refuge, in ca≈øe the King ≈øhould ever change his Affection towards him. Thus, what was a Capital Crime in the Huguenots, who made a con≈øiderable part of the State, and what would have driven out of the Kingdom the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Per≈øons next to the King (unle≈øs they had cho≈øen rather to be confined to a Pri≈øon) was e≈øteemed a ju≈øt recompence for the great Services of Cardinal Richlieu. The Prince of Conde, who was ≈øent from one Province to another, to pacifie the Spirits of tho≈øe who might be ≈øurpri≈øed at the exce≈ø≈øive greatne≈øs of a Mini≈øter, who cau≈øed him formerly to be put in Pri≈øon, went ba≈øely publi≈øhing his Prai≈øes all over the Kingdom, and yet was not able to get into the Favour of this Man, who could bear with nothing that gave him any Jealou≈øie. See Aubery, Lib. 11. Cap. 17. He had made already, in the Year 1628, a Panegyrick upon this Mini≈øter before the States of Languedoc, with Expre≈ø≈øions onely fit to come from a wretch that wanted Bread, and had no other ways to ≈øub≈øi≈øt: but this was nothing in compari≈øon of what he ≈øaid in the A≈ø≈øembly of the States of Britany. I ≈øhall relate his very words, that thereby the Reader may judge both of the mean Conde≈øcen≈øions of the Prince, or of the Mini≈øter's great Authority.

See Aubery, Ibid. Lib. ‚Ä¢ . Cap. 19. Among≈øt tho≈øe infinite Obligations you have to the King (≈øaith he) either for having pre≈øerved your Privileges, or for the great Advantages favourably granted to your Province of Britany, even almo≈øt
to an impo≈ø≈øibility in regard of the other Provinces of his Realm, you have contracted a new one, which is the greate≈øt of all; for His Maje≈øty has given to you Mon≈øieur the Cardinal of Richlieu for your Governour, who≈øe Learning and Piety preferr'd him in his younger years to a Bi≈øhoprick, his De≈øerts to a Cardinal's Cap, his Services and Capacity to the Mini≈øtry of State Affairs, his Valour to the General≈øhip of ≈øeveral Armies; his Fidelity and Love for the King's Per≈øon to the Cordial Affection of His Maje≈øty; and as a Token thereof, and of his Tru≈øt to the High Places and Governments, which he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth and holds from him. All which things, though very con≈øiderable and great, yet we may ≈øay neverthele≈øs of them, that they onely make up the lea≈øt part of tho≈øe recompences which he ju≈øtly de≈øerves; for having in his fir≈øt Dignity confounded Here≈øie, in the ≈øecond maintained the Church, in his Employments ≈øtrengthened the State by his Coun≈øels, by his Valour pull'd down and defeated Rebellion, and extended the Limits of France into Italy, Lorraine, and Germany, and by his Fidelity, with a continual care, watched for the King's Pre≈øervation; under who≈øe Command he hath always acted as a ≈øecond Cau≈øe, in tho≈øe great Affairs, which His Maje≈øty had, and hath yet, to re≈øtore the Kingdom to its fir≈øt Splendour. The Prince had better have ≈øaid, As a fir≈øt cau≈øe; ≈øince the King did nothing el≈øe but blindly follow the Motions of his Mini≈øter, and then he had ≈øaid at lea≈øt one true thing in his Speech, which was worthy of none but ≈øome Poor Hungry Prie≈øt, and not of a Prince who a≈øpired formerly to the Crown. For indeed, What could the King have done more in favour of this Cardinal, but to A≈ø≈øociate him to the Crown by a Publick Declaration, or rather to yield it wholly to him, con≈øidering he had received but the lea≈øt part of that Recompence which he de≈øerved? After this, there is no rea≈øon to wonder, that private per≈øons flattered the Cardinal, ≈øince the Princes of the Blood offered him their Incen≈øe in ≈øo ≈øhameful a manner. Therefore from this time may we almo≈øt date the univer≈øal Extinction of that generous love for Truth, which formerly, if we may ≈øo expre≈øs our ≈øelves, made Martyrs among≈øt the very Pagans. Nothing
having been fa≈øhionable in France, ever ≈øince the exce≈ø≈øive Authority of the Cardinal, but ful≈øome extravagant Flatteries, and Stories made on purpo≈øe to advance ones Fortune at the Expence of Truth and Sincerity.

The ≈øame Prince Siri Mem. Rec. T. 7. P. 360. who≈øe Words I have related, was ≈øent by the King into Provence, under pretence to a≈ø≈øemble the States; but in effect to ≈øound their Inclinations, to ob≈øerve the Conduct of the Duke of Gui≈øe, whom the Cardinal hated, and to le≈ø≈øen the Authority of the Governour of that Province, both by the Dignity of his Per≈øon, and the Power he had received from the King. The Cardinal had cau≈øed the Marquis of Saint Chamond to be made Lieutenant for the King in Provence, with a De≈øign to cro≈øs the Duke of Gui≈øe in any thing which he might undertake again≈øt the Authority of the Mini≈øtry. The Prince of Conde wrote to the Duke of Gui≈øe, to de≈øire him to come to Avignon, and confer together concerning ≈øome Affairs relating to the Crown, not telling him what they were. The Duke being offended at this Proceeding, ≈øent word back again, he could not go to wait upon the Prince beyond the Confines of Provence, and complained to the Cardinal of the haughty manner he had been dealt with. The King had been informed that he kept a ≈øecret Intelligence with the Spaniards, and had Intentions to invite ≈øome of their Troops into Provence. Nay, it was reported, that the Duke of Feria had received Orders to ≈øend two thou≈øand Italians, and five hundred Spaniards to Barcelona, to embark 'em there for Provence. Whether it was really ≈øo, that the Duke of Gui≈øe had invited a foreign Power to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance again≈øt the Mini≈øter, or it was only an Artifice of his Enemies, to render him ≈øu≈øpicious to the King, the Cardinal advi≈øed his Maje≈øty to ≈øend an Order to the Duke of Gui≈øe to come to Court. He refu≈øed at fir≈øt to obey, fearing, with rea≈øon, to be ≈øent to the B ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ le, or to Bois de Vincennes; and he obtained, at la≈øt, the King's Leave to make a Journey to our Lady of Loretto; from whence he retir'd to Florence, under the Protection of the Great Duke of Tu≈øcany.

This Prince became ≈øu≈øpected to the Cardinal, Siri ibid. P. 444. becau≈øe it was thought that he ≈øent Money ≈øecretly to the
Queen-Mother, and that he favoured the Spaniards. It was for this Rea≈øon that Gondi, who had been at Florence for ≈øome time about his own private Affairs; at his Return to France, in the Month of November, received Orders immediately to be gone, and had much ado to obtain Permi≈ø≈øion to ≈øtay. Once as he had Audience of the Cardinal, this Mini≈øter gave him a long Narrative of the Di≈øcontents of the Queen-Mother, and of all that had pa≈øs'd between them ever ≈øince the Beginning. He a≈ø≈øured him, that he had never given her any Occa≈øion to be angry with him, but that ≈øhe had fallen into a Pa≈ø≈øion upon Trifles; and that by ≈øuffering her ≈øelf to be too much influenced by ≈øome People who de≈øired nothing ≈øo much as to cau≈øe Di≈øturbances at Court, in order to cultivate their own particular Intere≈øt, ≈øhe had for≈øaken the King to embrace the Party of the younge≈øt of her Sons; that he (the Cardinal) was willing to withdraw him≈øelf, to take away all occa≈øion of Divi≈øion in the Royal Family; but that the King would not permit him to do it, not believing him≈øelf to be ≈øafe without him, and not thinking fit he ≈øhould have ≈øo much Conde≈øcen≈øion for tho≈øe who had dealt with him ≈øo unworthily: ≈øo that having been thus forc'd to remain at Court, he was willing, both as a Chri≈øtian, and as one that had infinite Obligations to Their Maje≈øties, to reconcile them together, that he might avoid thereby the Nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øerving the King again≈øt his Mother; that not being con≈øcious to him≈øelf of having ever offended this Prince≈øs, he had de≈øired of her, that ≈øhe would be plea≈øed to tell him what Rea≈øons ≈øhe had to complain of him, and even to ≈øuppo≈øe, if ≈øhe would, any Wrong, which he had never done her, to ≈øupport what ≈øhe had ≈øaid again≈øt him, becau≈øe he would not contradict her, and if condemned, he was ready to make her any publick Satisfaction for it; but that ≈øhe an≈øwered nothing before the King, but only that ≈øhe would never be reconciled to him; that the Wrong which ≈øhe complained to have been done to her, was that which ≈øhe ≈øaid the Cardinal had done both to the King and State: That he had ≈øerved her, during fourteen Years, with all po≈ø≈øible Fidelity and Zeal; but that being fallen out with him, ≈øhe would not hearken to
any Accommodation, and ≈øought every day an Opportunity to have him murther'd; which obliged him to take care for the Pre≈øervation both of his Life and Fortune; and therefore he had not rejected the King's mo≈øt gracious Offers made to him to change tho≈øe Mini≈øters who did not plea≈øe him: That the Queen was never a Pri≈øoner, and that to ≈øatisfie her that ≈øhe was free, they had removed the Soldiers that were about her: That ≈øhe was to be blamed for retiring into Spain, and that Animo≈øities were now grown to ≈øuch a degree, that the King could not be reconciled with ≈øafety.

This Di≈øcour≈øe made Gondi believe the ≈øame thing, which ≈øeveral Per≈øons had already ≈øu≈øpected; viz. that the Cardinal knew that the Queen had a mind to retire, and therefore was glad to leave her the means to effect it, that ≈øo he might have an Occa≈øion to accu≈øe her of keeping an Intelligence with the Spaniards, and to hinder the People from being offended at her Bani≈øhment. The Party of this Prince≈øs, which was linked with that of Mon≈øieur, was extremely weak, as wanting both Friends and Money. The Severities u≈øed again≈øt their Followers kept back a great many others who would have otherwi≈øe joyned with them; nor cou'd the Queen-Mother borrow any Money upon her Jewels, becau≈øe People feared that the King wou'd demand them again, as belonging to the Crown. The King on his ≈øide was ≈øo incen≈øed again≈øt his Mother, that there was no likelihood he would tru≈øt her again, as well by rea≈øon of her Corre≈øpondence with the Spaniards, as becau≈øe ≈øhe had declared her ≈øelf for the Duke of Orleans, who ≈øhe believed would infallibly ≈øucceed to the Throne after the King's Death, which, according to the Predictions, was to happen very ≈øoon. Contri≈ø≈øon being arrivedThe 14th of February. at Paris, acquitted him≈øelf the next Day of his Orders, and went to carry his Letters of Credence to the Cardinal. When he ≈øaw in the Sub≈øcription of the Letter, Cardinal-Duke of Lorrain, he ≈øaid that this was a plea≈øant ≈øort of a Quality, by way of Contempt, as if the Title of Cardinal-Duke had only belonged to Armand John du Ple≈ø≈øis, exclu≈øively of all others. To this the Cardinal of Richlieu replied, in a great pa≈ø≈øion, That now it plainly appeared that the Cardinal of Lorrain (for he never vouch≈øafed to call him Duke) would follow the Foot≈øteps of his Brother: That the≈øe An≈øwers, full of Di≈ø≈øimulation, and very different from what he had promis'd by word of mouth, did ≈øufficiently di≈øcover his De≈øign, as they formerly found by what Spirit he acted, when after he had denyed that he knew any thing of his Si≈øter's Marriage, it was now di≈øcovered that he had granted a Di≈øpen≈øation for the Banns: That till then they had believed the Cardinal of Lorrain was a Prince of Honour and Sincerity, whereas they found him at pre≈øent to be the quite contrary: That if he refu≈øed to ≈øend the Contract, it was a Matter of no great Importance, ≈øince they cou'd ea≈øily di≈øcover after what manner it was done: That if they ≈øti≈øled the Original Papers, it would be ≈øo much
the ea≈øier to get the Marriage annull'd: That they very well knew who were the Witne≈ø≈øes, and that as for them and the Monk, who had di≈øappeared, the King would let them ≈øee, to their Co≈øt, that he had long Hands. At la≈øt he concluded, That whereas he had been formerly a Friend to the Cardinal of Lorrain, he wou'd be his greate≈øt Enemy if he continued to follow the Maxims of his Brother.

As for what concerned the Taking of Saverne, the King, according to the Cardinal, was not obliged to make any Excu≈øes for what had been done upon very ju≈øt Grounds: And he added, That if the Cardinal of Lorrain had defended it, they wou'd have taken it away from him by force: That they wou'd con≈øider what was to be done to the Governours of tho≈øe Places which his Maje≈øty held in tru≈øt, who had hinder'd the Duke of Lorrain from rai≈øing his Duties: That in≈øtead of allowing farther time for him to do Homage for the Dutchy of Bar, he mu≈øt expect every moment to ≈øee it declared lap≈øed to the King, by the Duke's Felony, and incorporated to the Crown, and that the Principal might well follow the Acce≈ø≈øary. His meaning was, that they might ju≈øtly enough ≈øeize upon all Lorrain by vertue of a Decree of Parliament which wou'd be inflicted upon the Duke by way of Puni≈øhment for his ≈øtealing away Mon≈øieur, and for the Charges of War.

After this manner it was that the Cardinal-Duke pretended to oblige tho≈øe, that were weaker than him≈øelf, to ≈øubmit to his imperious Will, under a Pretence of doing Ju≈øtice to the King's Reputation. All his Mini≈øtry was ≈øupported by the ≈øame Arrogance, becau≈øe he had to do with Per≈øons of very ordinary Di≈øcretion; and having full Power to oppo≈øe them with the Forces of the Kingdom, and all the King's Authority, he cru≈øhed and overwhelm'd them, before they were in a condition to ward his Blows.

While the Di≈øcour≈øe at Paris ran upon the Duke of Lorrain, and every one imagined that he wou'd at la≈øt marry Madam de Combalet, to appea≈øe her Unkle, he At Luneville, the 16th of F ‚Ä¢ b. Ladies, and a Gentleman. The Rea≈øon why he took this Re≈øolution, and put it ≈øo ≈øpeedily in Execution, was becau≈øe he feared that the Mare≈øchal de la Force, who was at the Head of the King's Army not far from thence, came with a De≈øign to take the≈øe two Prince≈ø≈øes, and to ≈øend them into France, which might furni≈øh that Court with a plau≈øible Occa≈øion to ju≈øtifie the Rights which they pretended to have upon Lorrain, to the prejudice of the Princes of that Hou≈øe. In Effect the Mare≈øchal de la Force having received Advice of this Marriage, cau≈øed Luneville to be Siri Mem. Rec. Tom. 7. p. 740. inve≈øted, and conducted the newmarried Couple, with the Dutche≈øs of Lorrain and the Prince≈øs of Phaltsburg to Nancy, where they were kept in Confinement, although they were otherwi≈øe treated with a great deal of Re≈øpect. This New Married Prince, whom we ≈øhall hereafter call Duke Nicholas Francis, ≈øent a Gentleman to the Court of France, to acquaint the King with his Marriage, and to de≈øire him to order Luneville to be re≈øtored, and him≈øelf and the Prince≈øs to be ≈øet at liberty, ≈øince he was ready to ob≈øerve all the Treaties that had been made with His Maje≈øty. As for what related to his Marriage, they told his Envoy, That the King did not concern him≈øelf about it; but they denied he was a Pri≈øoner, ≈øince he had liberty to walk all over the City of Nancy. But ≈øo far were they from delivering up any thing which they had taken, that under pretence that the Cardinal was of the ≈øame Humour with his Brother, they ≈øaid, The King was obliged, for his Security, to ≈øeize upon the remainder of Lorrain. In the mean time Duke Charles offer'd to deliver up la Mothe and Biche, two ≈øtrong Places, which he ≈øtill kept in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, into the King's hands, if he would ≈øet his Brother and the Prince≈ø≈øes at Liberty.

But the Court of France thought it better to take them by main Force, and not to part with the Prince and Prince≈ø≈øes, who≈øe Rights they de≈øigned to make u≈øe of: So the Mare≈øchal de la Force was ordered to Block up la Mothe, till ≈øuch time as he could formally Be≈øiege it.

The Prince≈øs of Phaltsburg was kept more clo≈øely confin'd at Nancy than any of the re≈øt, becau≈øe ≈øhe was of a Spirit much more difficult to manage, and had been the principal cau≈øe of her Si≈øter's Marriage. But as ≈øhe was the Per≈øon who found out means for that Prince≈øs to make her e≈øcape, ≈øhe contrived a way to e≈øcape her ≈øelf, notwith≈øtanding the Guards, by hiding her ≈øelf in the Seat of a Coach that was to carry one of her Gentlemen who was Sick, and Maimed in one of his Legs, out of the City, by vertue of a Pa≈øsport he had procured. Within nine Miles of Nancy ≈øhe and her Cripple got on Hor≈øeback, and took the way to Be≈øanson. Duke Charles, who was in Al≈øatia in the Imperial Army, de≈øign'd in the mean time to ≈øurprize the French Camp before La Mothe, and having obtain'd ≈øome Troops of the Imperial Generals, he joyn'd them with his own, and marched on that ≈øide. But neither did Duke Nicholas Francis, nor the Dutche≈øs his Wife, think them≈øelves obliged to expect the end of this Tryal in Lorrain; ≈øo having found an opportunity to e≈øcape out of Nancy in a Di≈øgui≈øe, they retired to Be≈øancon, and from thence to Florence; only the Dutche≈øs Nicole, the Wife of Charles, ≈øtill tarried in Nancy, in the Hands of the French. While this pa≈ø≈øed in Lorrain, the Cardinal made great Promi≈øes to Mon≈øieur and Puilaurens to draw them into France, for fear lea≈øt Ga≈øton ≈øhould reconcile him≈øelf to the Queen-Mother. Chanteloube to write to Bouthillier, that ≈øhe was re≈øolved to come and throw her ≈øelf upon his Maje≈øty's Genero≈øity, and to be reconciled to the Cardinal of Richlieu, if the King commanded her to do it. The King open'd it in the Cardinal's Pre≈øence, where, be≈øides what is related above, he found that the Queen demanded a Pa≈ø≈øport to ≈øend one la Roche, who might come and go as Bu≈øine≈øs required. F. Chanteloube ≈øaid that the Queen demanded nothing more for him, but that he might

Upon this the King a≈ø≈øembled a Council, who as they were ≈øurpri≈øed to ≈øee the Queen-Mother pa≈øs from one Extremity to another, ≈øo they imagin'd that there was ≈øome Artifice in this unaccountable Conduct. What help'd to confirm them in this Belief, was, that this la Roche had been the Accomplice of Alfe≈øton, and that another Man, who had been lately ≈øent to the Ba≈øtile, accu≈øed F. Chanteloube afre≈øh. So they an≈øwered the Bearer of this Letter by word of mouth, That ≈øo ≈øoon as the Queen removed F. Chanteloube, and writ with her own hand, they wou'd give more Credit to it, than to ≈øuch blind In≈øtructions as the≈øe were, which they had now received.

Upon the Arrival of this Me≈ø≈øenger to Flanders

P. 761., the Queen-Mother di≈øpatch'd de Laleu with three Letters, of her own Writing, one to the King, and the other two to the Cardinal and Bouthillier; the Contents of which were, That ≈øhe was ready to do whatever His Maje≈øty de≈øir'd of her, and particularly to be reconciled to the Cardinal, that ≈øo ≈øhe might obtain Permi≈ø≈øion to return to Court. body.p: THE Sieur Bouthillier having given me to under≈øtand from your Part, that my Misfortunes ≈øen≈øibly affect you, and that being concerned to behold me ≈øo long depriv'd of the Honour of ≈øeeing the King, it wou'd be a great Satisfaction to you to procure me that Happine≈øs; I thought my ≈øelf obliged to a≈ø≈øure you by the Sieur de Laleu, with what Plea≈øure I receive your kind Inclinations. Repo≈øe Confidence in him, and believe that I ≈øhall be with all Sincerity.

div.p: The In≈øtructions of de Laleu ran to this Effect, That he ≈øhou'd wait upon the Cardinal, and tell him that the Queen-Mother had not the lea≈øt Re≈øentment for what was pa≈øt: That ≈øhe de≈øired to make no other Advantage of tho≈øe Profe≈ø≈øions of Friend≈øhip which he made her, than to fix her ≈øelf again, by his Intere≈øt, in the King's good Graces, and obtain leave to ≈øend ≈øome of her Servants to him to negotiate her Return: That as for him≈øelf, he had no rea≈øon to be apprehen≈øive of the Queen-Mother, ≈øince he was infinitely the more powerful of the two, and ≈øhe wou'd always be commanded by him. De Laleu was order'd to ob≈øerve whether the Cardinal expre≈øt any Diffidence or no, becau≈øe if he did, it was an infallible ≈øign that it wou'd be in vain to think of an Accommodation. As for Father Chanteloube, the Queen wou'd not remove him of her own proper Motion; but if the Cardinal excluded him out of the Treaty, as he him≈øelf de≈øired, he promis'd to withdraw of his own Accord.

This Gentleman having thus deliver'd the Queen-Mother's Letters, and executed his Commi≈ø≈øion, Siri. Ibid. p. 761. the Cardinal found him≈øelf extreamly embarra≈øs'd, becau≈øe that ≈øince this Prince≈øs had humbled her ≈øelf to ≈øuch a degree, as it was never expected ≈øhe wou'd conde≈øcend to, all the World wou'd be of opinion, that the King cou'd not refu≈øe to give her Leave to come back to Court, without the Imputation of an unnatural Severity. However, he did not find him≈øelf di≈øpo≈øed either to believe that his old Benefactre≈øs cou'd heartily forgive him the Vexations he had cau≈øed her, or to pardon this Prince≈øs for her manner of treating him before ≈øhe left France, and for the Writings ≈øhe had cau≈øed to be publi≈øhed again≈øt him after her Departure. Be≈øides, he pretended to have received Advice from ≈øeveral hands, that Father Chanteloube de≈øign'd him a Mi≈øchief, and that he had written to ≈øome of his Friends, that the Queen wou'd never abandon him, altho' he had de≈øired her to leave him in Flanders. At the bottom this was but an incon≈øiderable Matter, and which he might ea≈øily have prevented afterwards, if the King had pre≈øerv'd any Tenderne≈øs for the Queen his Mother, and if the Cardinal cou'd have re≈øolved to forgive a Prince≈øs who in her time had
done him incomparably much more Good than Harm.

But the King, in≈øtead of being influenc'd by tho≈øe Con≈øiderations that naturally pre≈øented them≈øelves to his Mind, was ea≈øily per≈øwaded by the Cardinal to per≈øi≈øt in his Demands, that ≈øhe ≈øhou'd deliver up to him ≈øome of her Dome≈øticks, in order to receive farther Puni≈øhment; which ≈øhe cou'd not do without renouncing the Principles of Humanity, and frighting all tho≈øe Per≈øons from her Service that ≈øhou'd have any Inclinations to ≈øerve her. So de Laleu being ordered to come to Ruel, The 19th of Febr. where the King was to meet him with the Cardinal, he accordingly went thither, but was ≈øurprized to find only the latter there. However, he was received with extraordinary Civility, and the Cardinal told him, that the profound Re≈øpect he had for the Per≈øon that ≈øent him, obliged him to ≈øhew him more if it were po≈ø≈øible. But his An≈øwer made it ≈øufficiently appear with what Sincerity he delivered this Complement. He told him, That the Queen-Mother had always been welcome, but that his Maje≈øty was willing to be ≈øatisfied that ≈øhe wou'd never be di≈ø≈øwaded from that De≈øire ≈øhe then expre≈øt wholly to ≈øubmit her ≈øelf to his Plea≈øure, by tho≈øe malicious Spirits that had deceived her hitherto, and of which he could never be fully a≈ø≈øured, ≈øo long as they were in the World: (for now it ≈øeems they were not content to have the Queen di≈øcard them, when they ≈øaw ≈øhe was inclined to do it:) That for this end the King demanded of her to deliver into his hands Father Chanteloube, the Abbot of St. Germain, and the Fellow that calculated Nativities, (he meant Fabbroni whom he afterwards named,) becau≈øe they had not only injured the Queen, but likewi≈øe offended the King to that degree, that they mu≈øt never hope to be pardoned: The fir≈øt by his ill Coun≈øels, the ≈øecond by his ≈øeditious and wicked Libels, and the third by his Predictions, wherein he had given out that the King had but a ≈øhort time to live, which had made the Queen-Mother li≈øten to pernicious Coun≈øels, di≈øorder'd the Royal Family, and done a mighty Di≈ø≈øervice to the State: That therefore the Queen-Mother ought, without farther delay, to ≈øurrender up the Man that had put the King's Life in que≈øtion, as Fabbroni had done;
the Man that by his defamatory Libels had endeavour'd to take away his Reputation, as the Abbot of St. Germain had notoriou≈øly done; and la≈øtly, the Man that by attacking the Life of His Maje≈øty's mo≈øt faithful Servants, gave him all the ju≈øt rea≈øon in the World to be apprehen≈øive of his own.

The Cardinal added, That this would be an effectual way to convince all Mankind that ≈øhe di≈øapproved of their wicked De≈øigns, and ≈øeem'd to te≈øtifie abundance of Joy that his Enemies had not been able to alienate the Queen-Mother's good Affections from him. He concluded with ≈øaying, That he cou'd not forbear to inform the Queen with the ≈øame Freedom he had ≈øpoken to her heretofore, that con≈øidering what had pa≈øt, it was impo≈ø≈øible but that the King mu≈øt ≈øtill have ≈øome Di≈øtru≈øt: and that ≈øhe mu≈øt re≈øolve to di≈ø≈øipate it entirely, in order to build her Reconciliation upon a ≈øure and la≈øting Foundation: after which ≈øhe wou'd receive all imaginable Marks of natural Tenderne≈øs and Affection from the be≈øt Son in the World, and ≈øhe wou'd ≈øee the Effects of the ≈øincere Inclinations of one of her Creatures, who in this Juncture cou'd not di≈ø≈øent from the King's Intentions, without offending him ≈øen≈øibly.

Before de Laleu return'd to Bru≈ø≈øels, he received fre≈øh Letters for the King and Cardinal, in which the Queen-Mother confirm'd the ≈øame things, in terms ≈øtill more humble and conde≈øcending, particularly in regard to the Cardinal. While the≈øe Negotiations were managed by the Queen-Mother, Mon≈øieur con≈øulted the Univer≈øity of Louvain about his Marriage, which they judged to be valid, and he got it to be ≈øolemnly confirmed by the Archbi≈øhop of Malines, in the pre≈øence of ≈øeven Witne≈ø≈øes. The Queen-Mother was de≈øired to be pre≈øent at this

However, when ≈øhe received the abovementioned News, ≈øhe was ≈øo far from complying with tho≈øe di≈øhonourable Submi≈ø≈øions they expected from her, that ≈øhe be≈øtowed upon the Abbot of St. Germain the Place of her chief Almoner, which happen'd then to be vacant. But as the≈øe Rea≈øons only ≈øerved to cover their De≈øire to hinder Mon≈øieur from Marrying, the Pope, who was not prejudiced that way, formed great Difficulties upon all the Propo≈øals they made him.

The ≈øure≈øt Expedient was to get the Duke of Orleans into France, becau≈øe there they cou'd make him do whatever they had a mind to; for which rea≈øon they laboured in private to effect it, although this Prince pretended to be as far from entring into any Reconciliation as ever he had been. Puilaurens was extreamly out with the Duke of Elbeuf, and the latter complained of him, becau≈øe in the Treaty which was ≈øecretly making with the Cardinal, he had demanded nothing in favour of him, ≈øave only that he ≈øhould not be excluded out of the Amne≈øty. Tom. 8. p. 73. it happen'd that ≈øome unknown Bravo's attempted to murder Puilaurens, and di≈øcharged a Carabine loaden with ≈øeveral Bullets at him, as he was going up the Stairs at the Palace of Bru≈ø≈øels. The Count de Guicke al≈øo married a Relation of the Cardinal of the Hou≈øe of Ple≈ø≈øis Chivrai, and their Marriages were kept the ≈øame day at the Ar≈øenal with an extraordinary Magnificence. Puilaurens bought the Dutchy of Eguillon of the Prince≈øs Mary for ≈øix hundred thou≈øand Livres, and had very con≈øiderable Gratifications from the King; ≈øo that be≈øides his Quality of Duke and Peer, in which he was received in the Parliament on the 16th of December, he had an E≈øtate of above ≈øix hundred thou≈øand Crowns a year.

After having thus related the Di≈øorders of the Royal Family, and of Mon≈øieur's Reconciliation, in which the Cardinal had no le≈øs a ≈øhare than the King; 'twill be now nece≈ø≈øary to pa≈øs to Foreign Affairs, which took up this Mini≈øter at the ≈øame time.

The Dutche≈øs of Siri Mem. Rec. T. 8. p. 87. Lorrain, Wife to Duke Charles, who had re≈øided at Nancy, came by Order of the Court to Paris, where ≈øhe arrived the la≈øt day of April, and was received with great Re≈øpect, and conducted to the Palace of Lorrain. From thence ≈øhe went afterwards to Fontainbleau, where the King entertained her very courteou≈øly. However, as ≈øhe apprehended that when ≈øhe was at Paris they wou'd engage her in ≈øome Treaty, which might be contrary to the real Intere≈øts of her Hou≈øe, ≈øhe had made a Declaration before ≈øhe left Nancy, in the pre≈øence of a Notary, wherein ≈øhe ≈øignified, that being obliged by the King's Command to go to Paris, ≈øhe there prote≈øted, That whatever ≈øhe might do prejudicial to the Hou≈øe of Lorrain, was to be reckon'd null, as being extorted by force.

There was no longer any Di≈øcour≈øe now in France to make u≈øe of this Prince≈øs's Name to keep Lorrain, nor of the Guardian≈øhip of the Places deliver'd up by Prince Charles. The King's Commi≈ø≈øioners govern'd that Dutchy as if it had been a Conquer'd Province, and gathered the Revenues of it without any Di≈øturbance from the Duke's Officers. They augmented the Impo≈øts and Taxes, which exceedingly oppre≈ø≈øed the poor People, who ≈øtill continued well affected to their ancient Princes. About this time an Edict of the Duke of Lorrain was ≈øtuck up in ≈øeveral places, wherein he prohibited his Subjects to obey the French, whom he called U≈øurpers and Tyrants. This Edict gave ≈øuch Offence at Court, becau≈øe they imagined the Lorrainers knew the Contents of it to be true, that they immediately order'd the Parliament to re-a≈ø≈øume the Proce≈øs which had for ≈øome time been di≈øcontinued again≈øt the Duke, as a Va≈ø≈øal of the Crown, as well for the pretended Rape of Mon≈øieur, as for ≈øeveral other notorious Mi≈ødemeanours. For this end the Parliament ≈øent to Duke Charles to make his per≈øonal Appearance on a day appointed at the Palace of Lorrain, without having any regard to the Dutche≈øs that lived there, and complain'd of it to the Cardinal to no purpo≈øe.

While the Dutche≈øs was at Paris, the Mare≈øchal de la Force took the Ca≈øtle of Biche, and afterwards La Mothe, which ≈øurrender'd by Compo≈øition on the 28th of July, after which there remained no other places in Lorrain that dur≈øt hold out for the ancient Lords of this Country. Siri Mem. Rec. Tom. 8. p. 108. So the Parliament having confi≈øcated the Dutchy of Bar, the Cardinal cau≈øed the Decree to be executed with all imaginable Vigour. He erected a Court of Ju≈øtice at Nancy, which adjudged to the King abundance of Places in Lorrain, as having been alienated from the three Bi≈øhopricks of Metz, Thoul, and Verdun. He likewi≈øe got the Remainder of Lorrain to be ≈øolemnly ≈øeized upon, towards the Expences of the War, and obliged the Clergy, the Nobility, and the People, to take an Oath of Fidelity to the King. This Country was now look'd upon to be part of the Kingdom, which had formerly been taken from it by U≈øurpation and Violence; ≈øo that now they ≈øaid it was but ju≈øt to re-unite it to the
Crown; and to hinder the Lorrainers from making any In≈øurrections for the future, they cau≈øed ≈øeveral places to be di≈ømantled, where they might have lodged them≈øelves, unle≈øs the King would have kept Garri≈øons there, which wou'd have required a prodigious Expence.

The Cardinal had all along kept a mighty corre≈øpondence with the Swedes, till ≈øuch time as he thought he might be able to effect by Walle≈øtein's means a great part of what he did by the help of the Swedi≈øh Army. This man had got it into his Head to make him≈øelf be crown'd King of Bohemia, and to employ the Emperours Army again≈øt him≈øelf. He maintain'd a private Commerce with the Marqui≈øs de Feuquieres, the King's Amba≈ø≈øador in Germany, and the King promis'd to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him. As Walle≈øtein pa≈ø≈øed for one of the chief Captains of his time, and was extreamly beloved by the Soldiery, it was probable that he wou'd at lea≈øt give the Emperour a great deal of Trouble. It appears that upon this Expectation the Cardinal did not manage the Swedi≈øh Generals and Chancellour Oxen≈øtern with that Addre≈øs as he had formerly done.Siri Mem. Rec. T. ‚Ä¢ . P. 32. There was likewi≈øe a ≈øort of a Difference between them, becau≈øe they had refu≈øed to ≈øurrender Philipsburg to the King, of which place they had made them≈øelves Ma≈øters by compo≈øition. The King already was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øeveral Towns in Al≈øatia, the Bi≈øhoprick of Triers, and in the Neighbourhood; but Philipsburg was nece≈ø≈øary to him to ≈øecure and cover part of them.

While this Coldne≈øs between the Cardinal and the Swedes la≈øted, the Emperour having di≈øcover'd part of Walle≈øtein's De≈øigns, The 15th of February. Sui‚ñ™ H ‚Ä¢ d. p 53. cau≈øed him to be killed at Egra, a City of Sile≈øia, to which place he had retired; and ≈øo tho≈øe Projects which the Cardinal had formed, in hopes that Walle≈øtein wou'd in a ≈øhort time begin to act in concert with France, vani≈øhed in ≈ømoak. This News arriving to the King's Ears, he publickly ≈øaid, That all tho≈øe that betrayed their Prince de≈øerved the ≈øame fate. As for the Cardinal, he was ≈øo concern'd at his Death, that he cou'd not forbear ≈øaying, That the King might very well have ≈øpared to explain his Sentiments in publick. From this time it was nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øhew a greater Regard to the Swedes, who did not ≈øo much propo≈øe to them≈øelves to
free Germany from the Yoke of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, as to gain ≈øome Advantage by the War.

Upon the Occa≈øion of Walle≈øtein's Death, the King, con≈øidering the great Danger the Cardinal was in, by rea≈øon of the frequent Attempts that had been made upon his Life, thought it convenient to augment the Number of his Guards. Be≈øides tho≈øe he had before, he gave him 300 Mu≈øqueteers on Hor≈øeback; ≈øo that the Cardinal had now a compleat Sett of Guards, while the Queen-Mother was obliged to di≈ømi≈øs tho≈øe of her Dome≈øticks that were not of ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity to her, becau≈øe ≈øhe had not wherewith to maintain them.

The French accu≈øed ChancellourSui Mem. Rec. T. 7. p. 6 ‚Ä¢ 7.
Oxen≈øtern of De≈øigning to po≈ø≈øe≈øs him≈øelf of the Electorate of Mentz; and 'tis reported that Cardinal Richlieu had the like Ambition to make him≈øelf Elector of Triers.
Sim Mem. T. ‚Ä¢ . p. 113 To compa≈øs his Ends, he obtained of the Elector, by a good round Sum of Money, the Coadjutor≈øhip of the Bi≈øhoprick of Spire, and engaged him to ≈øend one of the Canons of the Church to Rome, to get his Bulls expedited for that place, as of his own proper motion, ≈øo that he might not be obliged to appear him≈øelf in this Affair. He only caus'd a Letter to be writ to the Count de Noailles, who had been lately ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadour to Rome, to ≈øupport the Demand of the Canon whom the Elector of Triers ≈øent thither, and to talk with the Pope and the Barberini's about it. The fir≈øt time that the In September. Amba≈ø≈øadour mention'd it to the Pope, his Holine≈øs an≈øwered, that it was not a thing to be done, as being oppo≈øite to the Concordats of Germany. Noailles, at his ≈øecond Andience upon this Affair, repre≈øented to the Pope, That ≈øince the Swed ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
were Ma≈øters of Spire, there was no other way to pre≈øerve the Catholick Religion in that City, but by granting the Cardinal his Bulls to make him Coadjutor there. He maintain'd be≈øides, that there was nothing in the Concordats of Germany which made a Foreigner uncapable to be Bi≈øhop of Spire. The Pope ≈øent back the Amba≈ø≈øadour to the Cardinal of the Datary; and as the Court of Rome is ≈øeldom guilty of acting with Precipitation, the Emperour had time enough to be informed of Cardinal Richlieu's De≈øign, and laid ≈øuch power≈øal Impediments in the way, that this Affair came to nothing.

At the ≈øame time the Duke of Weimar, and Mare≈øchal Horn, the Swedi≈øh Generals, The 6th of Septemb. lo≈øt the famous Battel of Norlingue, which put their Affairs in a bad condition, and gave terrible Apprehen≈øions to the Cardinal as ≈øoon as he received the News. He was afraid that the Imperiali≈øts wou'd utterly ruine the other Party in a ≈øhort time, becau≈øe they only ≈øub≈øi≈øted by their Victories. If that once happen'd, it was ju≈øtly to be feared that the Emperour's Forces wou'd pour into Lorrain, while the Spaniards enrer'd France by the way of Picardy or Champagne. Be≈øides, the latter threatned to make a De≈øcent upon Provence, and attack Languedoc by Sea. Be≈øides, they had ju≈øt rea≈øon to ≈øu≈øpect that the Duke of Savoy wou'd joyn them, becau≈øe they had not kept their Promi≈øe with him as to the Sum they had agreed to pay him for Pignerol. He cau≈øed Turin and Montmelian to be fortified, and had given ≈øome other ≈øigns of his being di≈øcontented. All this gave a great deal of Inquietude to the Cardinal, The 13th of September. Siri Mem. Rec. T. 8. P. 163. who had a long Conver≈øation with Father Jo≈øeph about it; and they concluded that the Prote≈øtant League was in very great danger, becau≈øe they were not in a condition to bring an Army into the Field pre≈øently: ≈øo that ‚Ä¢ t w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ b≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to relieve them with all ≈øpeed, as they de≈øired. Oxen≈øtern and the Confederates who had formerly refu≈øed to deliver up Philipsburg to France, were now willing to ≈øurrender it, and con≈øented to have a Bridge built there, and a Fort on the other ‚Ä¢ ide the Rhine, to defend it.

Thus the Affairs of Germany coming to be debated in the Council, the Cardinal was of opinion, That nothing could ≈øo much prejudice his Maje≈øty's Affairs as to expre≈øs any con≈øternation at the Defeat of Norlingue: That if the Prote≈øtant Party was entirely ruined in Germany, all the Forces of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtriae wou'd pour down like a Torrent upon France: That the condition of the Prote≈øtants demanded a ≈øpeedy and vigorous Relief, and a Name capable of giving courage to the Imperial Cities, who would otherwi≈øe di≈øengage them≈øelves from the League, and make a ≈øeparate Peace, as well as the other Members of which it was compo≈øed: That although France ≈øhould refu≈øe to interpo≈øe in the Affairs of Germany, yet the Hou≈øe of
Au≈øtria would be no le≈øs provoked again≈øt her, and only believe that this proceeded from her Weakne≈øs and Fear: That his Maje≈øty cou'd not po≈ø≈øibly act wor≈øe than ≈øo to manage Matters as to let France alone ≈øu≈øtain the ≈øhock of Au≈øtria, which wou'd mo≈øt infallibly happen if they did not take care to maintain the Party which had given that Hou≈øe ≈øo much trouble for ≈øo many years: That in re≈øolving to ≈øupport them, the wor≈øt that cou'd fall out was to keep up the War in Germany by the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Confederate Prote≈øtant Princes; whereas otherwi≈øe they mu≈øt ≈øoon expect to behold the ≈øame War in the heart of France, without having any Friends to help them: That therefore the be≈øt way wou'd be to encourage the≈øe Princes, to find out Money, and rai≈øe ≈øufficient Forces to ≈øtrengthen the Army of the Mare≈øchals de la Force and de Brez√©, who were appointed to command in Germany.

This Advice was follow'd, and Orders were ≈øent in the mean time to the Mare≈øchal de la Force, who was in Lorrain, to advance towards the Rhine to oppo≈øe the progre≈øs of the Imperiali≈øts, that already threaten'd to joyn the Army of the Marqui≈øs d'Aytone and of Prince Thomas, and with them to enter Lorrain. Several places of Al≈øatia and the Palatinate, which the Swedes were forced to abandon to form an Army out of the Forces of the≈øe Garri≈øons, put them≈øelves under the protection of France, that they might not fall into the hands of the Imperiali≈øts. The Mare≈øchal de la Force marched with 25000 Foot, and 4000 Hor≈øe towards the Rhine between Coblentz and Bri≈øac, and in the interim a new Treaty was concluded with the Prote≈øtant Confederates, who were promis'd great Supplies of Men and Money. In con≈øequence of this Treaty, the Swedes delivered The 7th of October. Philipsburg to the French, and the Prince of Wirtemberg, who was to be Governour of the place, took the Oaths of Fidelity to the King. The Cardinal was extreamly glad to ≈øee ≈øo important a City in the hands of his Maje≈øty, it being capable to ≈øtop the Imperiali≈øts, in ca≈øe they de≈øigned to pa≈øs the Rhine, to make their way into Lorrain; and the Mare≈øchal de la Force was order'd not to ≈øtir ‚Ä¢ ar from it, lea≈øt the Enemies ≈øhou'd attempt to carry it by force.

The Marquis de R√¥ny, who was Grand Ma≈øter of the Artillery of France, being dead, the Cardinal procured this place to be given to the Marqui≈øs de la Meilleroys,
Siri Mem. Rec. T. 8. P. 180, &c. his Cou≈øin, who had exerci≈øed it by Commi≈ø≈øion ever ≈øince the Marqui≈øs de R√¥ny was obliged to leave the Court. Not long after a Report was ≈øpread abroad, that the King was di≈øgu≈øted with the Cardinal, becau≈øe this Prelate per≈øwaded him to go in per≈øon upon the Frontiers of Germany, to encourage the Prote≈øtant Party. The King was better pleas'd to live at one of his Hou≈øes of Plea≈øure near Paris, than to engage him≈øelf in ≈øo tedious a Journey. 'Tis pretended by ≈øome, that his Confe≈ø≈øor put ≈øome Scruples into his Head, for a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Hereticks, for the Bani≈øhment of the Queen-Mother, and his Inva≈øion of Lorrain. It was ≈øome time before he wou'd ≈øee the Cardinal; but the latter having con≈øulted eight Divines of the Sorbone upon his Maje≈øty's Scruples, four of them made An≈øwer, that in the pre≈øent conjuncture of Affairs, his Maje≈øty was obliged to continue to act upon the ≈øame foot, to pre≈øerve Tranquillity in his Kingdom, and that this ≈øufficiently ju≈øtified his Conduct. Soon after, the King began a-fre≈øh to vi≈øit the Cardinal, and did him the honour to come to the Ca≈øtle of Chilly, where this Mini≈øter then was, to con≈øult with him as formerly about the mo≈øt important Affairs of the Crown.

year 1635 THE Duke of Orleans being now taken into Favour, and Puilaurens his Con≈øident ≈øeeing him≈øelf a Duke and Peer of France, they imagined that they had nothing more to fear, and that they might manage the Cardinal as they had formerly done. Siri Me ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Rec. T. 8. P. 107. So this Mini≈øter having ≈øent word to Puilaurens that if he cou'd per≈øwade Mon≈øieur to con≈øent to have his Marriage annull'd, they wou'd reward him with the Command of an Army, and make him a Mare≈øchal of France; Puilaurens laughed at this propo≈øal, and thought he might railly the Cardinal ≈øafely enough. Coudrai Montpen≈øier, who
had the greate≈øt credit with the Duke of Orleans next to Puilaurens, was of the ≈øame humour, and had as little Inclination to comply with the Mini≈øter's plea≈øure as the other. The Cardinal fan≈øied he was the Man that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Philaurens with the≈øe ambitious Thoughts; ≈øo that he re≈øolved to remove him. Upon this he tells Puilaurens, that ≈øince he had contracted ≈øo near an Alliance with him, he was de≈øirous to be united ≈øtill more clo≈øely to him, but that he cou'd not do it, ≈øo long as he kept Company with Coudrai Montpen≈øier, and reckoned him one of his be≈øt Friends. Whether Philaurens di≈øtru≈øted that the Cardinal had ≈øome De≈øign upon him, or el≈øe was re≈øolved to pay no farther regard to this Mini≈øter, in≈øtead of di≈øcarding him, as he was de≈øired, he gave him the next Apartment to his own; which procedure began to incen≈øe the Cardinal, whom all the other Mini≈øters obeyed at the fir≈øt word, and who cou'd not dige≈øt this Oppo≈øition from the Favourite of the Duke of Orleans, whom he had ≈øo far honour'd, as to give him one of his Relations in Marriage.

Mon≈øieur generally re≈øided at Blois, andSiri Mem. Rec. T. 8. P. 199, &c. it happen'd while he was there, that ≈øeveral Spaniards of Quality who travell'd from Flanders to Spain by Land, came to Blois to pay their Re≈øpects to him, who received them very courteou≈øly. He frequently mention'd the Gentlemen of that Country with great e≈øteem, as if he intended to ≈øhew his Gratitude for the kind Reception he found among them, and engage them to u≈øe Madam well, who ≈øtill continued in their Territories. This made Don Cri≈øtoval Benavides, the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour, ≈øay, That although Mon≈øieur left the Low-Countries without taking his leave; yet if he went thither a hundred times, and came back as often after the ≈øame manner, he ≈øhould ≈øtill find a hearty Welcome there. This Conduct of Mon≈øieur, and the Di≈øcour≈øes of the Spaniards, gave the Mini≈øters occa≈øion to ≈øu≈øpect, that he ≈øtill kept ≈øome private Intelligence with them, or at lea≈øt pre≈øerv'd an Affection to that Nation, which might be prejudicial to France in the pre≈øent po≈øture of Affairs. On the other hand, the Duke of Orleans continually prote≈øted, that if the King cou'd find any way to di≈ø≈øolve his Marriage legally, he wou'd not oppo≈øe it; but that he wou'd never go to tell
the Parliament a Sham-≈øtory that he was forced to this Match by the Princes of Lorrain, ≈øince he cou'd neither do it in Con≈øcience nor in Honour. He prai≈øed the Prince≈øs Margaret exceedingly, and preferr'd her infinitely, for her good Qualities, to his fir≈øt Wife. He frequently writ to her, and ≈øent her Money, Cloaths, Liveries for her Servants, two Coaches, and five thou≈øand Crowns a Month towards her Expence.

The Cardinal was of opinion, that this inflexible ≈øteadine≈øs of Mon≈øieur cou'd only proceed from the Advice of Puilaurens: nay, he pretended that this ≈øhew'd him to be ill affected to the King's Per≈øon, and that he de≈øired to behold the Duke of Orleans upon the Throne, that he might become chief Mini≈øter of State; as if the Marriage of Mon≈øieur had any relation to the King's Death. Puilaurens was accu≈øed of being familiarly acquainted with one Vieux-Pont, a Dome≈øtick of Mon≈øieur, who had ≈øpoken ≈øcandalou≈øly of His Maje≈øty. He was likewi≈øe charged with keeping a corre≈øpondence with the Hou≈øe of Lorrian; and that the rea≈øon why he approved this Marriage was, that this Hou≈øe might ≈øupport the Prince, in ca≈øe the King happen'd to die. Thus it was interpreted a Crime in the Duke of Orleans, becau≈øe he wou'd not depend upon the Di≈øcretion of the Mini≈øter for his Succe≈ø≈øion to the Crown; and yet this Mini≈øter mu≈øt be allow'd to take what Securities he pleas'd again≈øt the whole Royal Family, and all the Princes of the Blood.

The Cardinal, who had always taken great care to keep up that Jealou≈øie which the King ever ≈øince his Infancy had entertain'd again≈øt his Brother, ea≈øily per≈øwaded him that all the≈øe Practices of Mon≈øieur only tended to dethrone him, and that there was no other way to prevent the De≈øigns of his Dome≈øticks, but to de≈øtroy them. So the King was re≈øolved to apprehend Puilaurens; and that he might ex ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ute it with more facility, they were cont ‚Ä¢ iving of means to draw him from Blois to Paris. To effect this, a Ball was propo≈øed at the Carnaval, where Mon≈øieur and Puilaurens were invited to dance, as well as the King. They came to Paris upon this Occa≈øion, and Mon≈øieur was mightily care≈øs'd on all hands, though they cou'd not prevail with him to
make the lea≈øt ≈øtep towards the Di≈ø≈øolution of his Marriage.

The 14th of February was the Day agreed upon to apprehend Puilaurens; and the Guards at the Louvre were order'd to be doubled. This had like to have di≈øcovered their Plot; for a Footman belonging to the Duke of Orleans having ob≈øerved it, went to his Ma≈øter to bid him have a care of him≈øelf, becau≈øe the Court had ≈øome extraordinary De≈øign on foot. This Prince came to the Louvre about Two a clock in the Afternoon, to practi≈øe the Ball before-hand, when he received this Advice; but as fore≈øight was none of his Talents, he neglected it, and went to the King's Chamber, where he ≈øtayed till the Cardinal came there. They had ≈øent to find him out at the Keeper of the Seals, where he dined, and carried the Marqui≈øs Du Fargis and Coudrai Montpen≈øier with him. When he went away he took du Fargis to the Louvre along with him, and gave Orders for the other to be apprehended when he offer'd to be gone; which was accordingly executed. Every thing was ready at the Louvre to begin the Ball, and none of the Company were wanting but only Puilaurens, who made the re≈øt wait above half an hour after the time appointed; which made the King and the Cardinal ≈øu≈øpect that he was informed of the De≈øign again≈øt him. At la≈øt he came, and after he had di≈øcour≈øed ≈øome time with the King, the Duke of Orleans, the Cardinal, and other Noblemen of the Court that were pre≈øent, the King took Mon≈øieur by the hand, and led him to his Clo≈øet. This was the Signal they agreed upon with the Marqui≈øs de Gordes, and the Count de Charot, Captains of the Life-Guards, when they were to arre≈øt Puilaurens and du Fargis.

They immediately executed the King's Orders, and the≈øe two Dome≈øticks of the Mon≈øieur were taken up without any noi≈øe. The King, as ≈øoon as he had received notice of it, told this Prince what he had done, and at the ≈øame time embraced him, and a≈ø≈øured him that he was perfectly well ≈øatisfied with him. He added that Puilaurens was an ungrateful Wretch, and that Mon≈øieur cou ‚Ä¢ d never expect to be well ≈øerv'd by him, after his horrid Ingratitude to the Crown which had been ≈øo kind to him. The Duke ≈øeem'd to be ≈øomewhat concerned
at it; but fearing to be ≈øerved after the ≈øame manner him≈øelf, he ≈øaid he would abandon Puilaurens for ever, if he had made any unhand≈øome Returns to His Maje≈øty's Favours. The Cardinal came afterwards into the King's Clo≈øet, who≈øe Pre≈øence hearten'd Mon≈øieur a little, for he concluded that if there had been any De≈øign to apprehend him, the Cardinal dur≈øt not appear in that place. This Mini≈øter complimented him afre≈øh, and a≈ø≈øured him it was his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure, that for the future he ≈øhou'd a≈ø≈øi≈øt at the Council. Mon≈øieur asked him whether the King gave him leave to ≈øtir out of the Louvre, and go the Palace of Gui≈øe, where he lodged. Under his Mini≈øtry he made no Treaty, by which any more was granted to tho≈øe that had rai≈øed any commotions, than a bare impunity; but he never permitted them to have the lea≈øt ≈øhare in public affairs afterwards.

By a ≈øtrong, a ≈øteady and equal conduct, he knew how to make the be≈øt advantage of all the occurrences of that time, and turn'd the greate≈øt tempe≈øts into calms, where he peaceably enjoy'd the fr ‚Ä¢ its of his labours. In ≈øhort, after he had triumphed over his own private Enemies as well as tho≈øe of the State, he died in the highe≈øt pitch of glory, and in an extraordinary e≈øteem with his own Prince.
